title: Prisons: the Rule of Law, Accountability and Rights
descriptions:
The proposed project, "Prisons: the Rule of Law, Accountability and Rights" (PRILA), aims to examine the mechanisms for securing rights and accountability in European prisons. Through a focus on overlooked elements of accountability and rights experiences, PRILA will document the experiences of prisoners, prison staff, and accountability bodies, study the structures for fair and transparent decision-making, and assess compliance with human rights principles. By utilizing legal, qualitative, and quantitative research methods, PRILA seeks to transform and extend accounts of legitimacy in prisons, advance judicial review of administrative action, and enhance understanding of penal power experiences. The project will contribute to the fields of public and prison law, human rights, comparative law, and the sociology of punishment.

The objectives of PRILA include creating an account of accountability work experience and examining accountability structures as manifestations of penal ideologies. The project aims to advance conceptions of accountability, the rule of law, and fairness, support better penal policies and practices, and protect the rule of law and rights in prisons. The distinctiveness of PRILA lies in its focus on the European experience of penal concepts, providing valuable insights that can inform policy and practice in the region. Ultimately, PRILA seeks to promote just imprisonment, uphold rights, and ensure fair treatment of prisoners in European prisons.

The "Prisons: the Rule of Law, Accountability and Rights" (PRILA) project aims to examine the mechanisms for securing rights, accountability, and adherence to the rule of law in European prisons. This project is crucial as it seeks to ensure fair treatment of prisoners, uphold their rights, and promote just imprisonment and good order within the prison system. By focusing on the power differentials in prisons and the expression of public and prison law values, PRILA aims to address overlooked elements of accountability and rights experiences.

Through activities such as documenting the experiences of prisoners, prison staff, and accountability bodies, studying the structures for fair decision-making, and analyzing compliance with human rights principles, PRILA seeks to transform accounts of legitimacy in prisons, advance judicial review of administrative action, and enhance understanding of penal power experiences. The project will draw on disciplines such as public and prison law, human rights, comparative law, and sociology of punishment, utilizing a mix of legal, qualitative, and quantitative research methods.

The objectives of PRILA include creating an account of accountability work experiences and examining accountability structures as manifestations of penal ideologies. The project aims to contribute to advancing conceptions of accountability, rule of law, and fairness, supporting better penal policies and practices, and protecting the rule of law and rights in prisons. The distinctiveness of PRILA lies in its focus on the European experience of penal concepts, making it a unique and valuable contribution to the field.

The "Prisons: the Rule of Law, Accountability and Rights" (PRILA) project aims to delve into the European prison system to examine the intricate mechanisms that secure rights, ensure accountability, and uphold the rule of law. By focusing on overlooked elements of accountability and rights experiences, PRILA seeks to document the perspectives of prisoners, prison staff, and accountability bodies. Through a combination of legal, qualitative, and quantitative research methods, the project will study the structures for fair decision-making, appeal processes, and compliance with human rights principles within European prisons.

The significance of this project lies in its potential to transform and extend accounts of legitimacy in prisons, advance judicial review of administrative actions, and enhance our understanding of penal power dynamics. By bridging disciplines such as public and prison law, human rights, comparative law, and sociology of punishment, PRILA aims to contribute to the advancement of conceptions of accountability, rule of law, and fairness. The project's unique focus on the European experience of penal concepts sets it apart and positions it to support better penal policies and practices, protect the rule of law, and promote the rights of individuals within the prison system. Ultimately, PRILA seeks to create a comprehensive account of how accountability structures manifest penal ideologies in European prisons, with the overarching goal of promoting just imprisonment and good order.
